In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION  
1.  Since the adoption of managing for development results (MfDR), the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) has been promoting results-based management among its developing member 
countries (DMCs). ADB’s Strategy and Policy  Department developed an MfDR action plan 
(revised in August 2006), aimed at improving (i) DMC capacity for MfDR, (ii) ADB’s institutional 
effectiveness, and (iii) global partnerships. The first pillar focuses on integrating MfDR capacity 
development  with  regional  department  operations,  particularly  through  country  partnership 
strategies, and on promoting results-based public sector management (consisting of planning, 
budgeting, implementation, and monitoring and evaluation [M&E]) to support MfDR in DMCs. 
Strong country-led M&E systems are needed for DMCs to monitor progress and assess the 
results of development efforts toward achieving their Millennium Development Goals, and to 
integrate findings and lessons from evaluations into their planning and budgeting processes. 
              
2.  In support of ADB’s MfDR agenda, the Independent Evaluation Department (IED) has 
been providing evaluation capacity development (ECD) to enhance M&E capacities in selected 
DMCs through three regional technical assistance (TA) projects. Two of these TA projects 
provided support to some DMCs under ADB’s Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Program1 and 
under  ADB’s  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC)  Program,2 mainly  by 
sending  mid-  and  high-level  government  officials  from  key  agencies  dealing  with  M&E 
(e.g., ministries  of  finance,  planning,  and  economy)  to  attend  the  Shanghai  International 
Program for Development Evaluation Training (SHIPDET),3 which is an M&E-related training 
program cofinanced by the People’s Republic of China’s (PRC’s) Ministry of Finance, the Asia-
Pacific Finance and Development Center (AFDC), the World Bank’s Independent Evaluation 
Group, IED, the Asia-Pacific Community of Practice (APCoP) on MfDR, and the International 
Initiative for Impact Evaluation.4  These two TA projects altogether sent about 40 mid- and high-
level government officials to attend SHIPDET in October 2009 and about 50 officials in 2010. 
                                                
1  ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance for Capacity Development for Monitoring and Evaluation. Manila (TA 6410-REG). 
2  ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance for Capacity Development in Results-Based Monitoring and Evaluation for 
Countries under the Asian Development Bank’s Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program. Manila 
(TA 7348-REG). 
3  SHIPDET is an M&E training program, aimed to help strengthen the M&E capacities of DMC government officials 
and evaluation practitioners. It was initiated in 2007 by its co-sponsoring agencies, including the PRC’s Ministry of 
Finance and AFDC, the World Bank’s Independent Evaluation Group, and IED. The APCoP on MfDR and the 
International Initiatives for Impact Evaluation started to cofinance SHIPDET activities in October 2010. Since 2007, 
SHIPDET has been organized at AFDC in Shanghai twice a year—April (mainly for PRC officials and evaluation 
practitioners) and October (mainly for foreign officials and evaluation practitioners). IED has been sending selected 
staff to attend SHIPDET each October, and started sending relevant government officials from GMS and CAREC 
DMCs since October 2009. 
4  Starting in October 2010 under IED’s initiative, as supported by other SHIPDET co-sponsoring agencies, the 
originally lengthy 2-week SHIPDET was restructured into two programs, including 1-week core courses on basic 
M&E and another 1-week special topic courses on ―Impact Evaluation‖ and ―M&E and Results-Based Planning and 
Budgeting.‖ The restructuring of SHIPDET was in response to client demand that the 2 weeks’ length of SHIPDET 
be reduced so that participants do not have to be absent from work for too long. The restructuring of SHIPDET into 
two programs—each with a manageable length of 1 week—will help sustain the SHIPDET overall in the long run 
since each program is catered to two groups of participants. As such, each group does not have to be absent from 
work for too long and those who attended the special topic courses were not required to attend the core course first. 
This led to substantial increase in the number of overall SHIPDET participants by almost threefold, from about 50 
in 2009 to about 140 in 2010. Participants generally found the SHIPDET courses to be useful, particularly after the 
restructuring into two programs, which made the courses more focused and relevant to their needs. Restructuring 
of the SHIPDET courses was not only useful to clients and likely to help sustain the demand for overall SHIPDET 
in the long run, but also useful to AFDC since relevant AFDC staff were involved in the course design. This is a 
good learning-by-doing process that will help AFDC become a regional center of excellence in M&E in the future. 
Relevant AFDC staff will also be encouraged to make presentation in some SHIPDET sessions as trainers in the 
future.

2 
The GMS TA (footnote 1),5 which started in 2007 and was completed in late 2010, provided 
M&E training for trainers in its first 2 years in addition to sending these participants to SHIPDET 
in the last 2 years. The CAREC TA (footnote 2),6 which started in 2009 and will continue to 2012, 
will provide follow-on training at the end of the TA on self-evaluation and discussion with some 
former SHIPDET participants to find out about the actual utilization of the knowledge gained 
from SHIPDET and client satisfaction with SHIPDET. 
 
3.  The third IED TA project in support of ECD for DMCs is aimed at providing on-the-job 
training (OJT) opportunities at IED for up to four government officials from selected DMCs per 
year, for up to 5 months each.7 The TA covers 4 years of implementation, starting in 2011. 
There were three OJT participants in the first year, from Indonesia’s Ministry of Finance, the 
Philippines’ National Economic Development Authority, and the PRC’s Ministry of Finance. Each 
of them was assigned a mentor in their sector of expertise so that they could work as a team 
member  within  their  mentor’s  work  program  to  gain  hands-on  experiences.  The  first-year 
implementation of the OJT TA completed successfully, with mentors’ satisfaction on the outputs 
produced by the respective OJT participants as well as participants’ satisfactions with the overall 
OJT  program.8 The  participants  also  made  a  joint  presentation,  which  was  well  received, 
focusing on the relevance and usefulness of the OJT program, the intended utilization of the 
knowledge gained from the OJT program, and recommendations to improve the OJT program. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  In some DMCs, where M&E systems are results-based and well developed (integrated 
into the processes of performance-based planning and budgeting), the systems are considered 
a  driver  of  success  for  the  countries’  socioeconomic  progress.  Unfortunately,  good  M&E 
systems are not prevalent in many DMCs because of lack of demand (e.g., lack of awareness, 
good governance, and political will) and/or supply (e.g., lack of sufficient M&E capacities in 
various government agencies). Thus, increasing awareness and M&E capacity development is 
needed. 
 
5.  Various ADB departments have been providing support to help strengthen both the 
demand and supply sides of DMCs’ M&E capacities and systems as part of MfDR efforts. For 
example, regional departments have been doing so through their country partnership strategies. 
The APCoP on MfDR was established under the Strategy and Policy Department’s Results 
Management Unit. It was made up of senior government officials, acting as change agents to 
promote results-based approach to public sector management. The APCoP has established an 
MfDR framework centered on promoting certain results-based attributes that include results-
based M&E, along with results-based planning and budgeting. IED has been providing ECD 
support for MfDR through three regional TA projects—the recently completed GMS TA, the 
ongoing CAREC TA, and the ongoing OJT TA (paras. 2 and 3).   
 
                                                
5  The GMS TA sent about 20 officials from three GMS DMCs (Cambodia, the Lao People's Democratic Republic 
[Lao PDR], and Viet Nam) to attend SHIPDET in October 2009 and about 20 officials in 2010. It was completed at 
the end of 2010. 
6  The CAREC TA sent about 20 officials from four CAREC DMCs (Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan, and 
Uzbekistan) to attend SHIPDET in October 2009 and about 30 officials in 2010. It is ongoing and sent about 20 
officials to attend SHIPDET in 2011.  
7 ADB.  2010.  Technical  Assistance  for  Evaluation  Capacity  Development  through  On-the-Job  Training  at  the 
Independent Evaluation Department. Manila (TA 7767-REG). 
8  IED. 2011. First-Year Progress Report of the On-the-Job Training Technical Assistance. Manila.

3 
6.  To build on gains achieved from IED’s recently completed GMS TA, this proposed TA9 
aims to continue to support ECD in results-based M&E and related networking and knowledge 
sharing  activities  in  selected  DMCs,  mainly  in  the  same  GMS  DMCs  (Cambodia,  the 
Lao People’s Democratic Republic [Lao PDR], and Viet Nam).10 This is expected to complement 
IED’s ongoing CAREC TA and OJT TA. Based on the previous GMS TA, the participants found 
the M&E training provided by SHIPDET to be relevant and useful to their work, and requested 
additional ECD support to create a critical mass of beneficiaries in these DMCs to sustain the 
momentum gained.  
 
7.  The key lessons learned from the previous GMS TA are that there were no mechanisms 
to (i) assess actual utilization of the knowledge gained from SHIPDET, and (ii) mitigate the risk 
of  non-application  of  the  knowledge  acquired.  This  proposed  TA  aims  to  consolidate 
achievements from the previous GMS TA and address its lessons by incorporating a follow-on 
workshop in the TA design. This kind of workshop will not only provide additional ECD more 
directly related to self-evaluation, but will also provide an opportunity for sharing of experiences 
among selected former SHIPDET participants on their actual utilization of the knowledge gained 
from  SHIPDET  and  how  to  enhance  their  contributions  to  improving  their  countries’  M&E 
capacities and systems. The risk of low retention of SHIPDET participants will be mitigated by 
requesting the governments of the GMS DMCs to nominate staff who have been working in their 
current positions for at least 2 years, rather than entirely new staff who might not continue 
working  there.  The  proposed  TA  will  also  include  M&E-related  knowledge  sharing  and 
networking activities (e.g., introducing TA participants to M&E knowledge-sharing networks; 
networking with the Evaluation Cooperation Group; and support for the multi-donor regional 
centers for learning on evaluation and results, one of which is AFDC).  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome  
 
8.  The impact of the TA will be institutionalized results-based M&E systems to support 
MfDR in participating DMCs, as measured by the integration of self-evaluation findings and 
lessons  into  results-based  planning  and  budgeting  (by  mid-2014).  The  TA  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. The outcomes of the TA will be improved capacities and 
systems in results-based M&E in participating DMCs’ executing agencies and key ministries 
responsible for planning, budgeting, and M&E activities, as measured by the following (by mid-
2014):  
 
(i)  at least 70% of TA participants, who will be trained at SHIPDET are engaged full-
time in M&E functions; and 
 
(ii)  at least 70% of TA participants are involved in preparing self-evaluation reports of 
government- or externally-funded projects (by providing guidance to the agencies 
preparing these reports or by preparing the reports themselves). 
 
 
 
                                                
9   The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 12 December 2011. 
10  However, participants who had already been included in the training provided by the previous GMS TA will not be 
included in this proposed TA in order to provide opportunities for other relevant government officials. In addition, 
participants from DMCs other than the three GMS DMCs may also be included if need arises. The selection of 
participants from other DMCs will be based on (i) government requests submitted to IED, and (ii) the availability of 
funds that year after meeting the target number of participants from the GMS DMCs.

4 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  The TA covers 2 years (1 August 2012–31 July 2014), with the three GMS DMCs 
included  in  the  earlier  GMS  TA  (footnote  1)  to  consolidate  the  results  achieved  from  the 
previous efforts. The outputs of the TA will include the following M&E training and other ECD 
knowledge products provided to participating DMCs: 
 
(i)  The Shanghai International Program for Development Evaluation Training 
provided.  About  27 government  officials  from  executing  agencies  and  key 
ministries responsible for planning, budgeting, and M&E activities  in targeted 
GMS DMCs (Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and Viet Nam) will be nominated to train 
at SHIPDET each year for 2 years in October 2012 and October 2013 (or nine 
officials per DMC per year, four of whom to attend the SHIPDET core courses 
and five to attend the SHIPDET special topic courses). 
 
(ii)  A  4-day  follow-on workshop  provided.  Each of the three GMS DMCs will 
nominate11 about  10  former  SHIPDET  participants  (including  those  from  the 
earlier GMS TA), totaling 30 participants, to participate in this 4-day follow-on 
workshop, to be held in one of the three GMS DMCs (or at AFDC).12  The 
workshop, which will be provided by an international consultant in mid-2014, will 
consist of (a) a 2-day training on how to do self-evaluations (using IED’s project 
evaluation criteria and rating system applied to sample case studies); and (b) a 2-
day discussion with the participants to share their post-SHIPDET experiences, 
focusing  on  the  following  five  M&E-related  topics:  (1)  their  satisfaction  with 
SHIPDET; (2) the extent of actual versus intended utilization of the knowledge 
gained from SHIPDET, and how to enhance their contributions to improving their 
countries’ M&E capacities and systems in relation to planning and budgeting; 
(3) the  approximated  retention  rate  of  the  former  SHIPDET  participants  in 
performing  M&E-related  functions;  (4)  the  extent  of  their  direct  and  indirect 
involvement in preparing self-evaluation reports of government- or externally-
funded projects; and (5) the extent to which the findings and lessons from self-
evaluations are integrated into their countries’ planning and budgeting systems.13 
 
(iii)  Knowledge products created and disseminated. These outputs consist of (a) 
analyses of the survey results of client satisfaction with SHIPDET, conducted by 
AFDC (2009–2011); (b) M&E-related analysis based on experiences sharing on 
the five topics mentioned above, prepared by the international consultant who will 
be  providing  the follow-on  workshop  (in  mid-2014);  (c) TA  completion  report 
prepared by the same international consultant (in mid-2014); and (d) publications 
of the M&E-related analysis of the five topics and TA completion report prepared 
by the international consultant, and other related knowledge products.  
 
                                                
11 IED will request government nominations from the three GMS DMCs, based on availability of nominees and 
suitability from the governments’ points of view.  
12 IED will select the training venue. A good reason for selecting one of the GMS DMCs as the venue is that it will 
provide an opportunity for the consultant (who will be engaged to conduct the follow-on training) to spend one 
additional day interviewing supervisors of some former SHIPDET participants in that DMC to gain more insight into 
the five M&E-related topics described in para. 9(ii) and to verify the information obtained from the former SHIPDET 
participants. A good reason for selecting AFDC as the venue is that it will provide an opportunity for AFDC to be 
involved in the process of providing another kind of training, which will help its staff learn by doing to become a 
regional center of excellence in M&E in the future. 
13 Each of the former SHIPDET participants nominated by their respective governments to participate in the follow-on 
training will be requested by IED to prepare a PowerPoint file, focusing on these five M&E-related topics, to present 
and discuss during the experiences sharing session of the follow-on training.

5 
(iv)  Knowledge  sharing  networks  and  partnerships  developed  among  the 
Shanghai  International  Program  for  Development  Evaluation  Training 
participants  and  regional  centers  for  monitoring  and  evaluation.  These 
outputs  consist  of  (a)  introducing  participants  to  M&E  knowledge  sharing 
networks (e.g., the APCoP on MfDR), through which partnerships can be initiated; 
and (b) networking with the Evaluation Cooperation Group and providing support 
for the regional centers for learning on evaluation and results, which is a multi-
donor M&E partnership managed by the World Bank’s Independent Evaluation 
Group to promote regional centers of excellence in M&E (one of which is AFDC).  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $400,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on 
a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–other sources). Detailed cost 
estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  The TA will be implemented over 2 years (1 August 2012–31 July 2014). The executing 
agency  is  ADB,  with  IED  as  the  focal  point  to  implement  the  TA,  supported  by  other 
stakeholders (i.e., the Southeast Asia Department, resident missions of the three GMS DMCs, 
and AFDC). In August 2012, August 2013, and April 2014, IED will contact the Southeast Asia 
Department to request the three resident missions to nominate one focal point each, to liaise 
with the IED focal point and help transmit IED’s letters requesting the respective governments to 
nominate participants from relevant agencies dealing with M&E to attend SHIPDET in October 
2012 and October 2013 as well as the follow-on training in June 2014.  
 
12.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA has no 
procurement of equipment.  
 
13.  An  international  consultant  will  be  hired  for  about  3  weeks  in  mid-2014  to  do  the 
following: (i) in the first week, make necessary preparation for providing a follow-on training 
workshop; (ii) in the second week, provide a 4-day follow-on training workshop (footnote 12) to 
30 former SHIPDET participants from the three GMS DMCs, consisting of a 2-day training on 
how to do self-evaluations (using IED’s project evaluation criteria and rating system applied to 
sample case studies), and a 2-day discussion with the participants to share their post-SHIPDET 
experiences, focusing on the five M&E-related topics as described in para. 9(ii); and (iii) in the 
third  week,  prepare  an  M&E-related  analysis  of  the  five  topics,  together  with  a  brief  TA 
completion report, using the information from the M&E-related analysis of the five topics to 
evaluate the TA performance based on IED’s evaluation criteria. The consultant’s terms of 
reference are outlined in Appendix 3. Given the short-term nature of the international consultant, 
he/she will be engaged on an individual basis by ADB, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis for 
Supporting Evaluation Capacity Development and Networking in Selected Developing Member 
Countries, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3          11 
    OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANT 
 
1.  An international consultant (development evaluation specialist) will be engaged by the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB)’s Independent Evaluation Department (IED) for this technical 
assistance (TA), in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The consultant will be hired on an individual basis for about 
3 weeks or 21 person-days (which are equivalent to 15 working days) in year 3 of the TA—
around  mid-2014  or  8 months  after the  second  year  of  sending  participants  to  attend  the 
Shanghai International Program for Development Evaluation Training (SHIPDET).  
 
2.  The consultant will have (i) a graduate degree in economics or a related field; (ii) work 
experience in one or more of the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) countries; (iii) extensive 
experience in performing evaluation studies; (iv) extensive experience as a trainer on results-
based  monitoring  and  evaluation  (M&E)  and  performance-based  planning  and  budgeting; 
(v) proficiency in various computer programs (e.g., Word, Excel, and PowerPoint); and (vi) his 
or her own laptop computer. 
3.  The consultant’s major tasks will include the following: 
 
(i)  spending the first week at home to (a) review this TA paper, the analyses of the 
surveys results of client satisfaction with SHIPDET (conducted by the SHIPDET 
organizer or the Asia-Pacific Finance and Development Center [AFDC] in the 
past years), and other related documents to be suggested and sent by IED in 
order to obtain the necessary information in preparation for a 4-day follow-on 
training; (b) prepare course materials for a 2-day training on how to do self-
evaluations (using IED’s project evaluation criteria and rating system applied to 
sample case studies), as part of the follow-on training; and (c) prepare to hold a 
2-day discussion with the participants, as part of the follow-on training, to share 
their  post-SHIPDET  experiences,  focusing  on  the  following  five  M&E-related 
topics:  (1) their  satisfaction  with  SHIPDET;  (2)  the  extent  of  actual  versus 
intended utilization of the knowledge gained from SHIPDET, and how to enhance 
their contributions to improving their countries’ M&E capacities and systems in 
relation to planning and budgeting; (3) the approximated retention rate of the 
former SHIPDET participants for M&E-related functions; (4) the extent of their 
direct  and  indirect  involvement  in  preparing  self-evaluation  reports  of 
government-  or  externally-funded  projects;  and  (5)  the  extent  to  which  the 
findings and lessons from self-evaluations are integrated into their countries’ 
planning and budgeting systems;  
 
(ii)  spending the second week holding a 4-day follow-on training in one of the TA’s 
three GMS countries (Cambodia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, and 
Viet Nam) or at AFDC, consisting of (a) a 2-day training on how to do self-
evaluations (using IED’s project evaluation criteria and rating system applied to 
sample case studies); and (b) a 2-day discussion with the participants to share 
their  post-SHIPDET  experiences,  focusing  on  the  five  M&E-related  topics 
described  above,  and  providing  suggestions  to  them  on  how  they  could 
contribute more to improving their countries’ M&E capacities and systems (Note: 
if the training venue, to be selected by IED, is in one of the GMS DMCs, the 
consultant will spend 1 additional day interviewing supervisors of some former 
SHIPDET participants in that DMC to gain more insight into the five M&E-related

12  Appendix 3 
topics described above and to verify the information obtained from the former 
SHIPDET participants); 
 
(iii)  spending the third week at home to prepare (a) an M&E-related analysis (about 
5–10 pages) of the five topics mentioned above; and (b) the TA completion 
report (about 5–10 pages), using the information from the M&E-related analysis 
of  the  five  topics  to  evaluate  the  TA’s  relevance,  efficiency,  effectiveness 
(achievements of outputs and outcomes), sustainability prospects, and impacts; 
and identify lessons and follow-up actions (using the format to be provided by 
IED).
